definitions.description: Any sweet or sour, edible part of a plant that resembles seed-bearing fruit (see former sense) even if it does not develop from a floral ovary. A sweet or sweetish vegetable, such as the petioles of rhubarb, that resembles a true fruit or is used in cookery as if it was a fruit.
An end result, effect, or consequence; advantageous or disadvantageous result.
quotations: 1593; the fruit of rashness
1611; They shall eat the fruit of their doings.
1849–1861; The fruits of this education became visible.
2019; It is incontestably the case that future generations enjoyed the extraordinary fruits of the Industrial Revolution’s “great enrichment”.

definitions.description: Of, belonging to, related to, or having fruit or its characteristics; (of living things) producing or consuming fruit.
A homosexual man; an effeminate man. [from 1900]
quotations: 1977; "Moishe just checked in," he said. "He's a panhandler and a fruit. A disgrace to the Jewish race."
1984; I'm not talking to this twisted fruit anymore!
1997; Aww, but he's so cute! / He's a fruit… Oh my fucking god! You will not believe who was here today!

definitions.description: Offspring from a sexual union.
quotations: 1591–1592; King Edward's fruit, true heir to the English crown
1611; And she spake out with a loud voyce, and saide, Blessed art thou among women, and blessed is the fruite of thy wombe.

definitions.description: A crazy person.
Containing fruit or fruit flavoring.
Similar to fruit or tasting of fruit.
Crazy.
Effeminate, flamboyant; homosexual.
Sexually suggestive.
Alternative form of fruitie (“fruit machine”).
A state of engaging in extreme levels of stupidity.
quotations: 2018; Everyone is on both sides is going full retard about this Executive Order from Trump. No one is thinking rationally.
2019; They say never go full retard. America, thanks to democracy, eagerly embraced exactly that fate.
2024; "You're a real fucking character, John-O," he indicated as he began chuckling out loud seeing his friend being to perform what they both called the "full retard."

definitions.description: The setting on a magneto when the ignition spark occurs as late as possible, just before the piston reaches top dead center.
quotations: 1911; It is characteristic of the usual magneto to give an ignition spark at a somewhat lower speed with the spark control in the full advance than in the full retard position.

1915; Briefly, the objectionable features of the magneto are that the intensity of the spark depends directly upon the speed of the magneto—that is, the hottest spark comes at the highest speeds and the thin spark at the low speeds, that there is a difference in the intensity of the spark in the rang of full retard to full advance, and that with the use of the magneto there is the extra electrical unit that must be cared for.
1918; Interrupter set back of center at full retard, ½ inch.

definitions.description: Counterfeit money.
Money obtained in a devious or sneaky manner.
An outrageously high price.
Banknotes of any foreign currency.
A highly inflated currency.
Play money.
Amusing; humorous; comical. [from mid-18th c.]
Strange or unusual, often in an unpleasant way. [from early 19th c.]
quotations: 2002; Oh it's a funny time of year / There'll be no blossom on the trees

definitions.description: Showing unexpected resentment.
quotations: 2011; 'Moved in where?' Sam asked Brona in confusion. 'What boyfriend?''Glen,' Brona said quietly. 'You met him a while ago, remember? He only moved in last week. I was going to tell you but […] I thought you might be funny about it, that's all.'
2012; Ash would have been happy to sit and stare at Viv all day, but when he saw the other guys staring at his sister, too, he got funny about it.

definitions.description: Homosexual; gay.
quotations: 2005; Funny man ah get drop like a bad habit.

definitions.description: A joke.
quotations: 1996; After church I am met by a dear parishioner who says, "Got a funny for you. Father." Now I'll have "funnies," so I can reply. "Got one for you too, Mary!"
2014; Everyone would be sitting on big fluffy white clouds singing songs, telling funnies and just enjoying the day.

definitions.description: A comic strip.
quotations: 1974; Chic Young, who created his funny funny, “Blondie,” in 1930, and kept it the most popular comic strip in the world right through the unfunny generation, was quick to see the difference between the innocent funnies and the new generation of comics that started after the Second World War:

2014; The artist gave priority to “Mark Trail,” usually spending at least eight hours a day on it, then working at night on “The Ryatts,” a funny that featured the foibles of a family much like his own, which included four children.

2009; His father was more likely to listen to the radio, although he would read the Sunday funnies, and his grandmother would only read the Italian language paper she picked up at the corner candy store.

definitions.description: Humor in general.
A narrow, clinker-built double-ender for sculling.
quotations: 1810; I myself recollect the funnies at Eton, which were certain little boats, capable of containing one person only, who, like an Indian in his canoe, was constantly obliged to balance himself, with such critical nicety, that the least mistake was certain of producing a ducking.
1841; As I do not belong to the boat-club, I always row by myself in a funny […] or at least go in a two-oared boat, with some friend with whom I should otherwise be walking.
1971; We were going to have a go in one of the double scull ‘funnies’ that could be had from the Rowing Club in the harbour, but he is off up the line tomorrow to rejoin his old Battery.
1999; There was a great market for leisure boats, too: no wherries any longer, but whole fleets of punts, rowing gigs, funnies, skiffs, whiffs and randans […]

definitions.description: A deep cut.
quotations: 1961; Then Beowulf too rallied. With his whetted dagger he slit a gash in the serpent's middle.
1983; The victim of the attack, Russell Mills, suffered a head gash, a broken knee cap and a broken wrist.

definitions.description: A vulva.
quotations: 1962; “Oh Gertie it’s true. It’s all true. They’ve got a horrid gash instead of a thrilling thing.”

definitions.description: A woman.
quotations: 1934; "Will you bastards quit singing the blues? You're young, and there's plenty of gash in the world, and the supply of moon goes on forever," Simonsky said.

definitions.description: Rubbish, particularly on board a ship or aircraft.
quotations: 1960; […] each man was on 'gash duty' about once in eighteen days.
2007; You will learn flight safety, aircraft duties, uniform, SEP, oxyCrew, gash cart, safety card, bar seals, life jacket, diagram, uplift, C209, plonky kit, Crew lounge!
2024; After scradge and another mug of tea I washed up, tipping the slops into the gash tin […]

definitions.description: Nonsense.
quotations: 2025; I hope you don't mind, but instead of “a load of gash” in this paragraph, could we say, “completely without merit”?

definitions.description: Something low quality.
quotations: 2012; This new one he's got for free off a friend (I think), but it's absolute gash. It's huge and doesn't fit in with the deco of the room, but because he's got it for nowt he's not arsed about that.
2017; When you load up the game, the first thing you notice is that it looks like complete and utter gash. Everything is made up of ugly blocks.
2020; Well, this chap's obviously just cooked a pile of rancid old gash, no?

definitions.description: Unused film or sound during film editing.
Poor-quality beer, usually watered down.
Of poor quality; makeshift; improvised; temporary; substituted.
Spare, extra.
quotations: 1987; "All gash kit? There won't be no trouble with the books?"

definitions.description: ghastly; hideous
Synonym of gay: a homosexual man.
quotations: 2005; ‘Gaylord!’ ¶ ‘Bum-chum!’ ¶ ‘Chutney Ferret!’

definitions.description: Term of address to any man or boy.
An effeminate or insufficiently masculine man or boy.
Used to express dislike: lame, uncool, stupid, burdensome, contemptible, generally bad.
A large carton that fits on a pallet, used for transporting goods.
quotations: 2009; They come sorted according to type, in large cardboard gaylord boxes (you'll see pumpkins in these containers at supermarkets) or shrink-wrapped on a pallet.

definitions.description: A male person.
quotations: 1922; You are a silly young geezer.
2023; See the hoverboard-riding geezer? This close to payin' a G for a shot of my cousin Calvin's molars.

definitions.description: Someone affable but morally dubious; a wide boy.
quotations: 2002; Geezers need excitement / If their lives don't provide 'em this, they incite violence / Common sense, simple common sense
2003; He turned out to be a proper geezer who was willing to listen to my proposition that if he took the door at the Ministry, I would pay him £400 a month to mark my cards.
2009; He was a bit of a geezer. Used to box with the Krays when he was a young 'un.
2013; When I'd first met Adam, at work when we were both 23, the fact that he seemed a little rough around the edges appealed to me. He was a bit of a geezer, a joker, one of the lads.

definitions.description: Term of address for a male.
An old person, usually a male, typically a cranky old man.
quotations: 1885; In the right-hand division lay the two old geezers, as Sandy styled the landlord and his wife.
2000; The technical term for a female geezer is "old broad," but this is irrelevant, as nobody in Hollywood makes films about women over 55.
2014; Why Geezer? Why would a fine arts gallery choose a name that conjures images of a grumpy old guy sitting on the front porch hollering, “get off my lawn”?

definitions.description: Wife; old woman.
quotations: 1882; He'd flirt and boat, but never wrote / A note to his old geezer.
1886; This frizzle-headed old geezer had a chin on her as rough well, as rough as her family, and they're rough 'uns.

definitions.description: Alternative form of geyser (“domestic water boiler”).
Any well-bred, well-mannered, or charming man.
quotations: 1897; I corralled the judge, and we started off across the fields, in no very mild state of fear of that gentleman's wife, whose vigilance was seldom relaxed.

1915; As a political system democracy seems to me extraordinarily foolish, […]. My servant is, so far as I am concerned, welcome to as many votes as he can get. […] I do not suppose that it matters much in reality whether laws are made by dukes or cornerboys, but I like, as far as possible, to associate with gentlemen in private life.
2011; She wanted to go see a movie called Gigi, which I was not too thrilled about. But being a gentleman, I bit my tongue and said, “Okay.”

definitions.description: Any man.

A man of gentle but not noble birth, particularly a man of means (originally ownership of property) who does not work for a living but has no official status in a peerage; an armigerous man ranking below a knight.
quotations: 1587–1588; And when their ſcattered armie is ſubdu’d:And you march on their ſlaughtered carkaſſes,Share equally the gold that bought their liues,And liue like Gentlmen in Perſea, […]
1593; But when Adam delued, and Eue ſpan,VVho was then a Gentleman?

1918; “ […] This is Mr. Churchill, who, as you are aware, is good enough to come to us for his diaconate, and, as we hope, for much longer; and being a gentleman of independent means, he declines to take any payment.” Saying this Walden rubbed his hands together and smiled contentedly.

definitions.description: An effeminate or oversophisticated man.
An amateur or dabbler in any field, particularly those of independent means.
quotations: 2004; Latrobe had extensive dealings with Jefferson, the most prominent gentleman-architect in the United States.

definitions.description: An amateur player, particularly one whose wealth permits him to forego payment.
A nasty person.
A child, especially a mischievous one.
Alternative form of get (“Jewish writ of divorce”).
An (often walled) area of a city in which Jews are concentrated by force and law. (Used particularly of areas in medieval Italy and in Nazi-controlled Europe.)
quotations: 2009; The Venetian ghetto, according to Sennett, was to provide protection from the unclean bodies of the Jews and their sullying touch. The Roman ghetto, on the other hand, was planned as an area for mission. It was supposed to collect the Jews in one place, so that it would be easier to convert them.
2010; […] concentrating the Jewish community into ghettoes. The Germans not only started the ghettoes, but they had also opened a concentration camp […]
2023; Established by the Germans in October 1940, the Warsaw Ghetto was the largest Jewish ghetto in German-occupied Europe.

definitions.description: An (often impoverished) area of a city inhabited predominantly by members of a specific nationality, ethnicity, or race.
quotations: 1998; Charlestown would also become one of Boston's three large Irish ghettoes.
1998; By 1960 the growth and development of Chicago's black areas of residence confirmed the existence of the city's second ghetto.

definitions.description: An area in which people who are distinguished by sharing something other than ethnicity concentrate or are concentrated.
quotations: 2006; Counterhegemonic spaces imagined as bounded territories ensure that heteronormativity is fixed beyond the borders of the gay ghetto. The rural and suburban lives of lesbian and gay people are made invisible and signified as inauthentic.
2007; The student ghetto, southwest of the centre, is inside the triangle formed by [three streets] and is full of open-air bars, internet cafés, fast-food shops — and students.

2001; They're back in the student ghetto now, on oak-shaded streets lined with run-down houses filled with nonnuclear families of all varieties and kinds. Safe now from the tractor beams of the horrible good Christians, […]

definitions.description: An isolated, self-contained, segregated subsection, area or field of interest; often of minority or specialist interest.
quotations: 1983; Abraham Merritt wrote for the pulps and never in his lifetime achieved critical success. Yet he had a devoted following in the science fiction ghetto who admired the clarity of his style and his power to evoke moods.
2012; Invent is undoubtedly the wrong word, but the push from government was crucial in getting the Internet out of its academic ghetto.

definitions.description: Of or relating to a ghetto or to ghettos in general.
quotations: 2012; Those residing in ghetto communities were particularly ill equipped to adapt to the seismic changes taking place in the U.S. economy; they were left isolated and jobless.

definitions.description: Unseemly and indecorous or of low quality; cheap; shabby, crude.
quotations: 2005; I had not used very many minutes on my phone. Here we pay for our minutes prior to using them, and it gets expensive. I did not want her using up all my minutes. That was very ghetto and disrespectful.

2007; In some kind of warped hometown loyalty, sometime during the conversation folks would stake their claim to owning the bottom. Philly is more ghetto than D.C. Or is it that DC. is more ghetto than Philly? Or Dallas (LA) is more ghetto than LA.
2010; One guest did not pay. One of my checks remained open. They bolted and hit the service door. A walkout. Very ghetto.

2011; It was like an awesome trip walking though the old house on Douglas, a lot had changed and my dad had it looking more ghetto than ever. He had a dog that he was watching while a buddy of his was in prison. It was a female Rottweiler

definitions.description: Characteristic of the style, speech, or behavior of residents of a predominantly black or other ghetto in the United States.
quotations: 2002; The music I liked was very ghetto and gritty. It was the stuff that didn't really cross over much, but spoke to a roots black experience. People don't understand this now, but the falsetto, crying singers were the most ghetto back then.
2007; You're the one that grew up in the suburbs and you act way more ghetto than I do.” “I am not ghetto.” Val said in an English accent and broke out laughing.
2005; I beat up my kid's principal. Can you get any more ghetto than that?

2008; He wasn't lying because, truth be told, I looked a lot like Halle Berry, only I was much thicker in all the right places and I was way more ghetto than Halle. And I had the tattoos and the attitude to match.
2010; Oh yeah, we played the whole thing, I mean we was acting more ghetto than what we was. We was talking slangs and giving dabs every time we said so

2010; Kesha rang us up, and instructed another girl in the back to add extra food to the bag. "Your girl is kinda ghetto ain't she?" I asked when we left the store. "No more ghetto than anyone else around here" he replied,

definitions.description: Having been raised in a ghetto in the United States.
A demon said to feed on corpses.
quotations: 1927; The other chamber had shown a pack of ghouls and witches over-running the world of our forefathers, but this one brought the horror right into our own daily life!.

1962; From my laboratory in the Castle eastTo the master bedroom, where the vampires feastThe ghouls all came from their humble abodesTo get a jolt from my electrodesThey did the MashThey did the Monster Mash.

definitions.description: A graverobber.
A person with an undue interest in death and corpses, or more generally in things that are revolting and repulsive.
A person with a callous or uncaring attitude to human life and suffering, particularly when prioritizing economic concerns.
quotations: 1950; Restored to bumptiousness, Peter arrived jauntily in the kitchen, to survey Mrs Dibble's body as a spectacle new to him, and remark, "So the old trout's done herself in properly this time, I'm told. About time she did, the way she's been going on here." "Shut up, you old ghoul, and help Dr Grimsby to carry her upstairs."

definitions.description: The pungent aromatic rhizome of a tropical Asian herb, Zingiber officinale, used as a spice and as a stimulant and acarminative.
The plant that produces this rhizome.
Other species belonging to the same family, Zingiberaceae, especially those of the genus Zingiber
A reddish-brown color.
A person with reddish hair; a redhead.
Vitality, vigour, liveliness (of character).
quotations: 1918; The position in the country and in this House might be well expressed by a reference to the recent activities of the ginger party in Great Britain — the party that demanded that more ginger be put into the conduct of the war.
1990; He had, however, "put some more ginger in two nights ago. Things move with exasperating slowness in this country.”
1919; The party managers demanded more “ginger.”

definitions.description: Ginger ale, or can or bottle of such (especially if dry).
quotations: 2018; Can you buy dry ginger in Croatia? If not what is an alternative?

definitions.description: Any fizzy soft drink, or can or bottle of such; pop; soda.
quotations: 2010; Here’s, um, not toast but bread, anyway. And a can of ginger.
2015; A lot of people will tell you ‘ginger’ tastes best in glass, and there is a science behind that,” says the company’s commercial director.
2016; Maybe I was naive in thinking that baking with fizzy juice (soda, ginger, pop, whatever your regional name for the stuff is!) would be straightforward.

definitions.description: Of a reddish-brown color.
quotations: 2003; My eyes track upwards past the shoes to a pair of skinny legs, skinnier than mine, then to a tight black mini. Above that is a crisp white shirt. And crowning the whole thing is a mop of the gingerest hair I’ve ever seen in my life.
2005; And her hair’s brilliant red. It’s even gingerer than ours.
2009; But as well as being a tough rugby player, Jammer [i.e., James Graham] also has the gingerest hair and palest skin in rugby (and possibly the world).

definitions.description: Having hair or fur of this color.
quotations: 2007; A chorus of ‘Aaah’s rose as they would in an episode of The Royle Family, while the gingerest boy in school swung his legs on the worktop and pretended he was Jamaican to be more like his mate sitting next to him, who wasn’t Jamaican either, but had parents who were.

2009; But now evolution has stepped in, the reds are starting to mutate into bright ginger versions of themselves – and they’re here to stay. Leading squirrel expert Tony Handeigh, 48, is excited about the new breed of squirrel and thinks we could see woodland warfare in the future. He says: “I’ve seen one close up and it’s more ginger than Mick Hucknall’s pubes. But when it’s angry it gets even more gingerer.”
2010; He had everything. The Catweazle beard, the headband, the long flowing locks and he’s got to be the gingerest footballer ever (sorry Scholesy).

2011; His frizzy ginger hair is all slicked down straight, his sideburns are trimmed, and he’s wearing a suit. […] That is the rudest thing that anyone has ever said to me! Coming from my own father means that it’s twenty billion times worse. ‘Well, you’re . . . you’re . . . you’re the gingerest person in the world!’ I don’t know if that hurt or not.

2017; The walls of Jupiter’s study were lined with bookshelves and framed photographs, mostly of strange landscapes and people. Jupiter himself only popped up in a few of them – younger, gingerer, skinnier, less beardy.

definitions.description: Very careful or cautious; also, delicate, sensitive. [from early 16th c.]
quotations: 1899; He’s going to get an interview about ten o’clock, making the old gentleman predict war, and we’ll get out the gingerest kind of a special on the strength of it!

1921; Wherefore, although for my own car I want the “gingerest” possible engine, I realise that it has shortcomings for the general market and I would commend to designers the ideal of an engine that shall be as “woolly” as possible, so long as its artificially restricted dimensions shall not cause its owner to find himself unable to tackle respectable gradients.

1928; “Coney Island” is by far the best picture the Hip has had. That says very little for a house that has held the worst, but this F. B. O. [Film Booking Offices] will do business this week for the Hip because it more than makes good under one of the gingerest of names. And a name that should draw by itself.
2006; They, the Rabbis, for better or for worse, were very ginger with this question.
2007; After a very ginger landing, everyone aboard was able to see up close how lucky they had been to reach base.
2009; Moving very slowly, taking extremely ginger steps, the woman felt beads of sweat dripping down from her body.

2011; My face hurt like a son of a bitch every time I placed even the gingerest of fingertips on it, but from what I could see from my reflection in the broad blade of my letter opener, it still hadn’t swollen.
2013; To walk, each crutch he kinda hopped forward a little and used his torso to drag his legs after, using them as the gingerest element of a tripod.
2015; Silence settles once more between us all, filled only by the gingerest of clinks of forks reluctantly hovering over flesh.

definitions.description: A homosexual.
Homosexual.
Of or pertaining to globalism.
quotations: 2019; From a globalist point of view, talk of threats to a local culture or identity can look like bigotry and even racism: what reason could there be for excluding people when we are all part of a welcoming, global culture?

definitions.description: An advocate of globalism.
A Jew, implying that Jews are more loyal to a global conspiracy than the country which they live in.[1]
One who believes that Adolf Hitler intended to extend the Third Reich beyond the continent of Europe.
One who believes international events are primarily caused by conflicts between great powers.
quotations: 1986; "Globalists" tend to view international issues in terms of US-Soviet rivalry, while "regionalists" see them more often as manifestations of local rivalries and problems.
1986; The authors suggest that the globalist emphasis among policymakers has increased during the Reagan administration.

definitions.description: An elemental (spirit or corporeal creature associated with a classical element) associated with earth.
quotations: 1811; He adopts the Rosycrusian fancy of Gnomes, spirits which inhabit the earth, and who by their power form the ores of metals, and all the wonders met with in the inmost recesses of the globe.

1837; Day belongs to the earthlier deities—the stern, the harsh, and the cold. Gnomes are the spirits of daily hours. Toil, thought, and strife, beset us: we have to work, to quarrel, and to struggle: we have to take our neighbours in; or, at least, to avoid their doing so by us.

2006; Gnomes are perhaps the most useful of the elementals.A gnome can carry a person with it as it swims through the soil, provided it is strong enough to lift the person. The gnome cannot, however, provide air for that person […] .

2007; Elementals are the consciousness guiding the four classical elements of earth, fire, air, and water. These elementals are depicted as gnomes, salamanders, diminutive faeries known as sylphs, and merfolk, known as undines, respectively.

definitions.description: One of a race of imaginary human-like beings, usually depicted as short and typically bearded males, who inhabit the inner parts of the earth and act as guardians of mines, mineral treasure, etc.; in modern fantasy literature and games, when distinguished from dwarves, gnomes are usually smaller than dwarves and more focused on engineering than mining.
quotations: 1936; When the trees were disposed of, the gnomes vanished again.
2011; There were not one but four gnomes standing at his feet. “I nearly trod on you,” Daniel said. “What are you doing here?”The gnomes just stood, looking up at him.

definitions.description: A person of small stature or misshapen features, or of strange appearance.
The mountain pygmy owl, Glaucidium gnoma, a small owl of the western United States.
A small statue of a dwarf-like character, often bearded, placed in a garden.
quotations: 1968; There were ornamental ponds and shrubs clipped into animal shapes, painted concrete gnomes sitting on mushrooms, pink flamingos standing on one leg[.]

2011; My mother-in-law, who swears she is a good Lutheran but is also the most powerful Witch I have ever met, also has at least a dozen small lawn gnomes peeking out from beside her shrubs, next to the lilac bushes, and hanging out with the roses. My husband has already started our collection; as of this writing, four gnomes and one moss-covered rabbit hang out in the shrubbery by the front door, two gnomes live in the dining room, and one guards the perpetual pile of to-do paperwork that lives next to the computer.

definitions.description: An upper atmospheric optical phenomenon associated with thunderstorms, a compact blue starter.
A banker, especially a secretive international one.
quotations: 1973; So far the major beneficiaries of the boom in gold have been deposed South American dictators, Middle Eastern potentates, and the gnomes of Zurich.
2002; The gnomes of Wall Street can trade on rumors, but Warren will only invest after the sale or merger has been announced.

definitions.description: A brief reflection or maxim; a pithy saying.
quotations: 2003; Thus, the gnome concerning the precarious nature of, and the potential suffering in, human life sent by the gods uttered by Electra is deconstructed by her choice of paradigm. By using Tantalos as an illustration, the play overturns the apparent meaning of the gnome.

definitions.description: Damned by God.
Used as an intensifier.
quotations: 2019; I know this may seem a bit out of the box, but isn't this a particularly lousy time in history for the Congress to go on vacation for six goddamn weeks.

definitions.description: A more emphatic form of damn.
Alternative form of goddam (“an English person, from French perspective”).
quotations: 2009; The goddamns (British soldiers) are coming / To steal your children. / Awaken! Awaken! / Acadian men / To save our heritage.

definitions.description: Alternative form of omer: a former Hebrew unit of dry volume equal to about 2.3 L or 2.1 quarts.
quotations: 1801; On the morrow, the 16th, after having offered to God the homer, they began eating the corn of the country; and the 17th the manna ceased to fall from heaven. What supports this calculation is, that the gomer, or sheaf, was offered the 16th of Nisan, in broad day-light, though pretty late.

definitions.description: A conical chamber at the breech of the bore in heavy ordnance, especially in mortars.
quotations: 1809; [Table] of dimensions of howitzers, stone and Gomer mortars, vol. 1. p. 250.
1847; All iron mortars now in use have gomer chambers and brass ones conical.

definitions.description: A stupid, awkward, or oafish person.
quotations: 2005; “Lordy Jeezus,” he said out loud. When did he become such a gomer?

2007; Okay, you wanted to go to the Big Apple, but didn't want to sit in traffic or feel like a country hic, as you stare up at all 'dem big buildins'. Try Universal Studios Florida's version of New York, where you can stare at all the fake big buildings all you want and not feel like a total Gomer.
2008; Everyone will have to guess who I want to dance with tonight, I thought. I'm not giving myself away to this bunch of gomers. That would be way too embarrassing.

definitions.description: An inept trainee or serviceperson.
quotations: 1993; These recruits were given such sobriquets as moron, idiot, or Gomer (after the television marine Gomer Pyle). There were constant comparisons between wayward recruits and animals or vegetables.

definitions.description: An opponent in combat or in training.
quotations: 2010; We were almost invisible in our tiger stripes and ghillie suits. However, as the unit marched by, a lone gomer broke rank and ventured into the high, wet saw grass that concealed our position.

definitions.description: An undesirable hospital patient, or a patient who does not need medical care.
quotations: 1976; Mumford (1970) noted that the terms ‘crock’, ‘gomer’, and ‘turkey’, were sometimes utilized by interns to designate different types of undesirable patients, and sometimes used synonymously. At Bayview, gomer was the preferred term

definitions.description: A dirty, senile, or otherwise unpleasant patient.
quotations: 2001; It was 3:00 a.m. and an elderly homeless person had just been admitted to the emergency room. [...] One resident seemed tired and angry and said, "I can't believe we got beeped out of bed for this gomer."

2008; As a consequence of their loss of their personhood, the medical subculture has coined a lexicon of pejorative, cynical, and insulting names for demented patients, the most common of which is "gomer."

definitions.description: A patient who does not respond to medical treatment.
quotations: 1985; The number of problems the two groups of patients presented to physicians was comparable; however, the pattern of their hospital stays contrasted dramatically. Gomer patients remained in the hospital longer than other patients, and had more consultations for diagnosis and therapy, and posed more diagnostic and therapeutic dilemmas for the physicians who cared for them.

definitions.description: A foolish or silly person or animal.
A pill or tablet containing a pharmaceutical which has hypnotic or intoxicating effects, especially a barbiturate.
quotations: 1953; Strong Cobb & Co. of Cleveland announced a new barbiturate which in overlarge doses will turn the stomachs of "goofball" addicts and would-be suicides.
1957; That night Marylou took everything in the books; she took tea, goofballs, benny, liquor, and even asked Old Bull for a shot of M, which of course he didn’t give her; he did give her a martini.

definitions.description: Silly.

A person of (South) East Asian descent (originally revolutionaries of the Katipunan then generally to any native of the Philippines, after the enemy and collaborators hid amongst them), but now especially: A Korean person (especially the North Koreans during the Korean War). A Vietnamese person (including, but not limited to, Vietcong in the Vietnam War).

1979; Of course, I've got so many confirmed kills I lost count. Nobody believes me because the gooks drag off their dead.

definitions.description: A foreigner (to the speaker), especially the (enemy) natives of a place the speaker's military is at war with or in. A black insurgent in the Rhodesian Bush War.

definitions.description: Grime or mud.

definitions.description: A dull or hapless person.

definitions.description: A bonnet (headwear).

definitions.description: A thug; a usually muscular henchman with little intelligence.

2016; Sending for the goon who sent for me / He's thinking he's hard, yeah, it's Little T

definitions.description: An enforcer or fighter.

definitions.description: A German guard in a prisoner-of-war camp.

definitions.description: A member of the comedy website Something Awful.

Not only did goons need to beat Imgur's mid-May deadline but they also needed to account for the possibility that Imgur would treat the download as some kind of attack and throttle it — a possibility that, it turns out, never came to pass.

definitions.description: A wine flagon or cask.
quotations: 2009; We drank goons of cheap wine.

definitions.description: A Sino-Japanese kanji pronunciation layer, considered the first Sino-Japanese kanji reading type used in Japan.
Grandpa, grandfather.
Old man.
plural of gramp
comparative form of green: more green

definitions.description: A newcomer; a recent immigrant.
A person with a passion for protecting the natural environment; an ecological activist.
Agent noun of green; someone or something which greens.
An environmentalist, someone who shows concern for the environment; often aimed at environmental extremists.

A person from Colorado; after the color of the Colorado license plate.

2000; The only way I could keep up with the veteran pickers was to pick almost every strawberry in my row — ripe, unripe, overripe or damaged. ... Then he would pay me 2 cents a quart for the good ones and charge me a penny for the "greenies."

definitions.description: A small, green object. A blob of nasal mucus; a bogey. Amphetamines used in baseball.

definitions.description: Any of various birds having predominantly green plumage. A green-headed sunbird (Cyanomitra verticalis), of Africa. A western silvereye (Zosterops lateralis chloronotus), of Western Australia.

These birds belong to a family more correctly called lorikeets, and as such, under the Fauna Protection Act, they are totally protected throughout Queensland.

definitions.description: The yellowtail rockfish (Sebastes flavidus), a fish in the family Sebastidae.

definitions.description: Diminutive of greenback.

definitions.description: An allowance of a certain amount of time or distance in starting, granted in a race (or other contest of skill) to the competitor possessing disadvantages; or an additional weight or other hindrance imposed upon the one possessing advantages, in order to equalize, as much as possible, the chances of success.

definitions.description: Left out of water, stranded on a beach, or in the stocks for repair, or in dry dock.

definitions.description: With no condiments.

quotations: 1886; How was it possible that I, a rational man, not unacquainted with the leading scientific facts of our history, and hitherto an absolute and utter disbeliever in all the hocus-pocus which in Europe goes by the name of the supernatural, could believe that I had within the last few minutes been engaged in conversation with a woman two thousand and odd years old?
1981; The ego thinks that his local time and space is all there is to reality, and that the busy affairs of state and trade are more important than a lot of obscurantist hocus-pocus.

definitions.description: Some action carried out to bring about change as if by magic; a trick; sleight of hand, trickery.
A conjurer.
A conjurer's trick.
A hollow place or cavity; an excavation; a pit; a dent; a depression; a fissure.
quotations: 1606–1607; To be called into a huge sphere, and not to be seen to move in't, are the holes where eyes should be, which pitifully disaster the cheeks.

1879; Orion hit a rabbit once; but though sore wounded it got to the bury, and, struggling in, the arrow caught the side of the hole and was drawn out. Indeed, a nail filed sharp is not of much avail as an arrowhead; you must have it barbed, and that was a little beyond our skill.

definitions.description: An opening that goes all the way through a solid body, a fabric, etc.; a perforation; a rent.

definitions.description: In games. A subsurface standard-size hole, also called cup, hitting the ball into which is the object of play. Each hole, of which there are usually eighteen as the standard on a full course, is located on a prepared surface, called the green, of a particular type grass. The part of a game in which a player attempts to hit the ball into one of the holes. The rear portion of the defensive team between the shortstop and the third baseman. A square on the board, with some positional significance, that a player does not, and cannot in the future, control with a friendly pawn. A card (also called a hole card) dealt face down thus unknown to all but its holder; the status in which such a card is. In the game of fives, part of the floor of the court between the step and the pepperbox.
An excavation pit or trench.
A weakness; a flaw or ambiguity.
quotations: 2011; But between the drinks and subtle things / The holes in my apologies, you know / I’m trying hard to take it back

definitions.description: In semiconductors, a lack of an electron in an occupied band behaving like a positively charged particle.
A security vulnerability in software which can be taken advantage of by an exploit.
A person's mouth.
Any bodily orifice, in particular the anus.
A vagina.
Solitary confinement, a high-security prison cell often used as punishment.
quotations: 1988; In late December a Washington State prisoner was involved in a scuffle with a guard who was trying to take him into the hole.
2011; Disciplinary actions can range from a mere write up to serious time in the hole.

definitions.description: An undesirable place to live or visit.

definitions.description: Difficulty, in particular, debt.

definitions.description: A human.

definitions.description: A white (Caucasian) person.

A sweatshirt with an integral hood and, sometimes, a large kangaroo pocket at the front.

definitions.description: foreskin
The hooded crow, Corvus cornix.
The tip of a toe of an ungulate such as a horse, ox or deer, strengthened by a thick keratin covering.

1834; Suffer none, from far or near, / With their rights to interfere; / No strange Abram, Ruffler crack— / Hooker of another pack—

definitions.description: A prostitute. [from 1845]

definitions.description: Any antiquated craft.

definitions.description: A worthless person; a hooligan or lout. [From 1930s.]

definitions.description: A pimp. [From 1950s.]

Hoon related offences include burnouts, doughnuts, drag racing, repeated driving while disqualified and high-level speeding. Offences are detailed in section 84C of the Road Safety Act 1986.

2009; The hoons piled out of the wreck brimming with righteous road rage, and were settling to the task of beating the shit out of Wozza, Mutton and the hapless wheelman when they discovered the plastic bag.

2012; [T]here is an overwhelming sense of youth as a social group with nowhere to go and nothing to do. […] Predictably, this has produced a series of strategies among young people through which to counter the boredom and frustration they often experience. One of the more spectacular – and illegal – examples of this is "hooning" (a localized term for dangerous driving) by young males. […] [H]oons transform the quiet, often sleepy streets of neighborhoods on the Gold Coast into playscapes of their own. […] Equally salient in the context of the present discussion is the random night-time appropriation by hoons of particular streets and neighborhoods on the Gold Coast in which to enact the collective rituals that give the hoon culture both internal cohesion and local notoriety.

definitions.description: An attempt or go at something. [From 1980s.]

Amongst these were 3 tailors; one woman 30 years old, was there smoking her pipe,—she had been in the habit of doing so for 3 years at the rate of 3 hoons daily,—before she commenced the habit of smoking had children but none since,—thinks that it is owing to the bad habit,—would like much to give up but is frightened.

1860; Examined thirty-one men. Their average consumption was six hoons. The greatest daily consumption by one man was fifteen hoons; the smallest, two. The average number of years they had been addicted to the smoking of opium was seven years and some odd months.
1999; Chinese Catty = 1.33 lb (605 g) / = 16 Tahil (liang or tael). / 1 Tahil = 10 Chee (chandu measures) / = 100 Hoon (fen).

definitions.description: A pagoda, a type of gold coin.

definitions.description: In the manufacture of porcelain, a large, conical brick structure around which the firing kilns are grouped.
A straitjacket.

1817; Diana Vernon, the most beautiful creature I ever beheld, in love with him, the bandy-legged, bull-necked, limping scoundrel!—Richard the Third in all but his hump-back!

1951; […] I stared up at the raw spots on his cheek and thought, there is no safety anywhere: a humpback, a cripple—they all have the trigger that sets love off.

definitions.description: A humpback whale.
A humpback salmon.
The state or condition of being an idiot; the quality of having an intelligence level far below average; mental retardation; intellectual disability.

An idiotic act or utterance.
A person of low general intelligence.
A person who makes stupid decisions; a fool.

2024; “One of the things that you write so beautifully, and your stuff is so fun to read, but you write about Trump, quote, ‘The way that you build a truly vicious nationalist movement is to wed a relatively small core of belligerent idiots to a much larger group of opportunists and spineless fellow travelers whose primary function is to turn a blind eye to things,’” Kennedy said, reading Taibbi’s own writing back to him.

definitions.description: Idiotic, stupid.

2025; Major parties have long relied on large-scale campaign contributions, and the LDP was only recently mired in an illegal fundraising scandal. Sanseito drew its support from smaller, individual donations.

definitions.description: Forbidden by established rules.

definitions.description: A spy operating abroad illegally and under non-official cover, without visible ties to his or her country’s authorities.

2022; Traditionally, illegals have been extremely hard for counterintelligence agencies to find, but in a world of biometric data, facial recognition software and open source investigation possibilities, it has become harder for Russia to keep its illegals below the radar.

definitions.description: A person with limited mental capacity who can perform tasks and think only like a young child, in medical circles meaning a person who lacks the capacity to develop beyond the mental age of a normal five- to seven-year-old child.

definitions.description: Destitute of strength, whether of body or mind; feeble; impotent; especially, mentally weak.

2024; The level of academic inbreeding differs between countries and continents. Macháček et al. (2022) reported that in North America only 31% of all researchers are inbred (based on 22 major fields of science), while in Asia, this proportion is 55%, in Western and Northern Europe 37% and in Central and Eastern Europe reaches nearly 79% which is the highest proportion of inbreeders on the global scale.

definitions.description: A plant or animal produced by inbreeding.
A person born of incest.
A member of an online subculture of people (mostly men) who define themselves as unable to find a romantic or sexual partner despite desiring one.
quotations: 2004; Though, involuntary celibates (or incels) shouldn't try to rationalize a dateless season or pass off sexual awkwardness as virtue; […]
2017; It is not clear when the term incels was coined, but the link between misogyny and violence against women has emerged on sites where incel communities gather.

2018; The incel ideology has already inspired the murders of at least sixteen people. Elliot Rodger, in 2014, in Isla Vista, California, killed six and injured fourteen in an attempt to instigate a “War on Women” for “depriving me of sex.”

2023; The framing of inceldom as an “adverse life circumstance”, repeated across the Wiki, lends credibility to the framing used by incels who wish to dissociate themselves from the common descriptions of incels as a ‘movement’, ‘ideology’ or ‘community’. […] This report finds that the Wiki is a site of attempts to divorce the concept of being an incel from believing in the blackpill, and we argue that this is intended as a means of both expanding the category of incels to make them politically relevant, and dissociating the label ‘incel’ from violent misogyny.

2023; Online forums dedicated to incel culture are a reliable way to see how the term evolved and is used today. A subreddit, or forum on Reddit, called r/incels was one of the most visible meeting places for self-identified incels until it was banned by Reddit in 2017 for “violent content.”

definitions.description: An individual who is not sexually active despite having such a desire.

quotations: 2001; People who are 'incel' are often suspected as being gay. It's annoying.

definitions.description: The place where water, air or other fluid is taken into a pipe or conduit; opposed to outlet.
